Posts.Content: Aug 8, 2014 11:06AM Dancermom1999 wrote: I was told by my oncologist that any tumor under 3mm cannot get an accurate result.  They do the onco test 3 times and ideally they need 1mm per test.     I have seen on the site where some women with tumors at 4mm have the onco test.  NCCN guidelines do not recommend chemo or the onco for tumors under 5mm.  You can register on the site at:  www.nccn.com.  Great information on the site.
Posts.Title: Oncotype test - too small IDC to test? kimag Lilac17

Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2014 05:04PM Dancermom1999 wrote: Hi Kimag: My IDC was 2.6 mm and I too was told by my Onc that it was too small to test.  I had my bi lateral in January of this year and on this Thursday I will have the final procedure in my reconstruction process.  Very pleased with my results.  I am on Tamoxifen but will change to an AI when post menopausal.

Posts.Content: Jan 1, 2014 07:08AM Dancermom1999 wrote: Hi 1Mindy:  mnmbeck is right...many great threads and wonderful sisters to help get you through this.  This site has been a godsend to me since I was diagnosed on November 17th.  My surgery is this Friday, Jan. 3rd. and I will be having a bmx and reconstruction with tissue expanders and then the implant exchange.  I have met some ladies that had this and are very pleased with the outcome.  Needless to say, I am so scared too.  I have never had major surgery before but the ladies I have connected with on the site have given me a good sense of what to expect.  2014 will be a good year for us.  We will get rid of this cancer and focus back on our lives. Hugs to you...Kathy
Posts.Title: Mastectomy with reconstruction coming up....VERY NERVOUS 1MindyydniM1 Skiergirl

Posts.Content: Jun 8, 2014 01:37AM Dancermom1999 wrote: Hello AlienWish: My mammogram also came back "highly suspicious of malignancy"  bi-rads 5.  95% that it was cancer, and yes, it was.  Most scariest moment of my life.  That was November 11, 2013.  I went for the biopsy and 3 days later the cancer was confirmed. I am hoping for you, you are in the 5%.  However, even if you are in the 95% like me, there has been such progress treating this disease.  I took the BRACA test and while it came back negative, I still opted for the bilateral mastectomy.  Fortunately the cancer was small and I did not need chemo.  I had immediate reconstruction with tissue expanders.  In March I had the exchange and just had the nipple reconstruction.  All of this is covered under the Womens' Cancer Rights Act.  Take one step at a time.   Once the biopsy comes back you will have a better picture as to what you are dealing with and how your team of doctors will treat you.  I so feel what you are going through at this moment.  Take deep breaths, focus on your beautiful children and anytime you are feeling scared reach out on this site.   The ladies here helped me through and we are all here for you.
Posts.Title: Highly Suggestive of Malignancy AlienWish angelaisscared

Posts.Content: Mar 6, 2015 10:33PM Dancermom1999 wrote: Hi Florida2015...By your name I assume you live in Florida.  I live in Ft. Lauderdale.   I was diagnosed Nov. 2013 and had bmx January 3, 2014.  My mom had breast cancer and my brother reminded me that our mother had her surgery on January 3, 1967.  I took that as a sign that my momo would be in the operating room with my surgeons on the 45th anniversary of her breast cancer surgery. She was an amazing survivor and passed away in 2006 from an unrelated disease. My faith has helped me through all of this since my mom is now in heaven.  I remember the day before my surgery we were having a family dinner - my husband of 25 years, my 23 year old son, 15 year old daughter, and me.  At the end of dinner my daughter who is a dancer got up and started twirling around.  Out of her hands I see a white dove and I shout, OMG I just saw a white dove fly out of Kaitlin's hands. They all looked at me like I was a bit crazy.  When I looked up on the intranet what they could mean it said it was a symbol that the holy spirit was with me.  I never cried again.. I have passed my one year cancerversary and have gone through 4 surgeries for reconstruction and am very pleased with my results.  Focus on yourself and be kind to yourself.  Believe in your doctors and if you don't then find new ones.  Take everything one day at a time.

Posts.Title: Wait time between diagnosis and surgery katiegrey Pupcake

Posts.Content: Jun 8, 2014 02:56AM Dancermom1999 wrote: AlienWish: I am so sorry. My post was not meant to scare you, but to let you know that if it is cancer, research has come so far.  My mom had breast cancer twice...1st time she was 39 and I was 6.  Second time she was 62.  She lived until she was 78 and died from something totally different.  I was 53 at diagnosis and am now 54.  Reality sucks, but even if it turns out to be cancer, there is a treatment for you to fight this.  We have 146,000 women on this site to help and support you.  You are not alone.  The wait is agonizing and once you find out for sure, you will have a different perspective.  Just remain focused on your beautiful children and you will fight this.
Posts.Title: Highly Suggestive of Malignancy AlienWish angelaisscared

Posts.Content: Aug 16, 2014 05:42PM Dancermom1999 wrote: Hi Sparkle: Once I go without my period for a full year I an considered post menopausal.  My last period was a very light one and it was in Oct. of 2013.  Prior to that I did not have a period for 4 months.  When they did my blood work in January when I was diagnosed, the blood work indicated that I was post menopausal but they will not consider you that until you go one full year without a period. This is what all my doctors have told me.

Posts.Content: Aug 15, 2014 10:56AM Dancermom1999 wrote: Hi kmag: I am on Tamoxifen and was fine at first but an having some issues now, primarily leg pain.  I have an appt. with my oncologist on Tuesday and will be discussing then.  My concern is that I have read a lot that Tamoxifen does not work as well with PR - even though I am ER+.  However, I have been told that is not true since my ER was 81% + and that was a good thing.  In Oct. I should be post menopausal and then would want to switch to an AI.  I have read that an AI works well with ER+ PR- so I am hopeful.  Other than that I feel amazing.  Work out every morning now at 5:30 am and have lost 30 pounds.  I have finished my breast reconstruction last Thursday and I am so very pleased with  my results.  I just pray this never returns and things continue to go well.  All the best.  Kathy

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2015 01:29AM Dancermom1999 wrote: I am so sorry your Mom is going through this but thankful she has you to help her through.  Did she get a birads rating? If it is highly suspicious for malignancy it would be rated a birads 5.  Unfortunately, Birads 5 has a 95% chance that it is breast cancer.  However, it also has a 5% chance it is not.  There have been women on these boards that had a birad 5 and it turned out to be benign.  I unfortunately was in the other 95% and mine turned out to be malignant.  That was almost 2 years ago and I am doing great.  Will pray for your mom and your family.
Posts.Title: highly suspicious for malignancy maxfaith maxfaith

Posts.Content: Aug 13, 2014 08:55PM Dancermom1999 wrote: kimag: I feel the same way you do and I still worry.   Again, I was told my tumor at 2.6mm was too small.  They need to do the test 3 times.  Results would not be accurate.  In all the research I have done, small t1a tumors ( less than 5 mm) are not recommended for Onco testing and have excellent prognosis. NCCN guidelines do not recommend chemo for tumors this small - the risks of chemo far outweigh the benefits.  I just pray this is so.  All the best. Kathy

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2014 02:41PM Dancermom1999 wrote: Hi Dakota: I had the same problem. After 9 months on tamoxifen I developed an enlarged uterus, a 10mm thickening of the endometrial lining, a 1.6 cm fibroid and a 2 cm ovarian cyst - ALL from the tamoxifen. I had a hysterectomy 3 weeks ago today, had it lapascopic 1 incision in belly button, 2 tiny incisions in abdomen and then take it all out thru vagina. Only missed work for 7 days - amazing - best decision I made - now I don't have to worry anymore about uterin or ovarian cancer.
